comments.body: Hmm, well, I think everything defines this macro now, but this still seems a strange place for it, could cause redefinition warnings. There is only one other include file that defines it, and only a couple that import `Python.h` (without it). We might want to rationalize all those imports at some point.

Should we be defining it via distutils instead?

At any rate, I'd argue that warnings only matter if they cause ci to fail (conversely: if you care about a warning, configure ci to make it fail)

I don't see any warnings for this, just noting the potential. What I could see doing is another include file, `npy_python.h` or some such, that pairs them up. The include guard would prevent multiple declarations. Or we can alway fix with a `#if !defined(...)`. Worth noting, but not worrying about yet.

> Should we be defining it via distutils instead?

Passing as `-D` to the compiler? Worth thinking about. Would want to audit the few places where it is not currently defined with the Python import.
All good suggestions, thanks for thinking about this,
